Interface ec.e.db.RtEncodingManager 
All Packages  Class Hierarchy  This Package  Previous  Next  Index

Interface ec.e.db.RtEncodingManager

public interface RtEncodingManager
extends Object
Objects that implement the RtEncodingManager interface are declaring they will handle various encoding policy decisions.

encodeObject(Object, RtEncoder)
Overrides encoding an object.
idForUniqueExportedObject(Object)
Overrides a type identifier for an object.
noteNewClass(String, int)
Callback to encoding manager whenever a class is encountered for the first time.
uniqueExportedObject(Object)
Returns an integer to use as an identifier for an object.
willEncodeObjectAsClass(Object)
Overrides the class name for an object.

willEncodeObjectAsClass 
  public abstract String willEncodeObjectAsClass(Object obj)
Overrides the class name for an object. By returning a non-null String to be used as a class name, willEncodeObjectAsClass() can claim an object is of a different class than it really is. if the manager does this, then it will subsequently be asked to actually encode the object using encodeObject() below. The trivial default encoder returns null, deferring to normal encode behavior.
encodeObject 
  public abstract void encodeObject(Object obj,
                                    RtEncoder coder)
Overrides encoding an object. If the class name string returned from willEncodeObjectAsClass() is non-null, then the manager will be asked to encode the object using this method. In this trivial default encoding manager, this method is not called.
idForUniqueExportedObject 
  public abstract int idForUniqueExportedObject(Object object)
Overrides a type identifier for an object. If this method returns a nonzero integer then that number becomes a type identifier to be used for this (kind of) object. This manager returns 0, which instructs the encoder to use its own mechanisms.
uniqueExportedObject 
  public abstract int uniqueExportedObject(Object object)
Returns an integer to use as an identifier for an object. If you returned a nonzero identifier from idForUniqueExportedObject() above, then this method gets called, requesting an object identifier (an integer) for this object. You can use this (e.g.) to maintain your own unique object identification scheme for objects of that type, or cause all objects of this type to decode as a known canonical (shared) instance.
noteNewClass 
  public abstract void noteNewClass(String className,
                                    int classCode)
Callback to encoding manager whenever a class is encountered for the first time. This method gives the encoding manager a chance to keep track of all class types. The trivial default encoder relies on the regular encoding mechanism and does nothing.
